instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turns off if battery connected
threads.message:
Hi All,

Hope somebody can point me right direction, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> minor liquid damage near the J3099, <CAPACITOR>C7677</CAPACITOR>/76/75, <RESISTOR>R1420</RESISTOR>/21, CC714/15, <RESISTOR>R1425</RESISTOR>, CC763/62, <RESISTOR>R1422</RESISTOR>/23 - all were affected by liquid, cleaned and replaced, machine now boots however after login loading bar reaches nearly 100% and it freezes fallowed by one loud fan spin and switches off, it boots into user account if battery is disconnected however it is dead slow since sensor is on battery now (cpu usage around 70%) however fan is acting normal if battery is connected, tested with good known battery, issue the same - battery connector area clean so as <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40 looks good as well.
If Mac left on login screen without typing in a password it charges battery fine and is running off the battery as well.
Would really appreciate any help with this one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turns off if battery connected
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turns off if battery connected
threads.message:
Yes tried that, as well as this "other sort" of SMC by Apple with T2 - CONTROL+OPTION+RIGHT SHIFT+POWER BUTTON and ordinary of course with keyboard and by disconnecting battery, 
Thanks
